p: Several researchers have reported antifungal [ 16] (pp. 31–35), antimicrobial [ 17] (pp. 693–703), antioxidant [ 18] (pp. 100–106), immunomodulatory [ 19] (pp. 103–109), hepatoprotective [ 20] (pp. 1292–1303) and nephroprotective [ 21] (pp. 692–699) properties of black seed in aquaculture practices. The positive effects of dietary black seed have been shown on the growth performance, biochemical and immuno-haematological parameters of Carrasius auratus [ 22] (pp. 285–290), Oreochromis niloticus [ 23] (pp. 1–4), Lates calcarifer [ 24] (pp. 496–503), Oncorhynchus mykiss [ 25] (pp. 193–197), Sparus aurata [ 26] (pp. 43–50), Anabas testudineus [ 27] (pp. 331–339) and Cyprinus carpio [ 28] (pp. 87–92), but to our best knowledge there is no information available regarding the use of N. sativa in rohu ( Labeo rohita) diet.
